column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column7: Mint's employee demography by gender indicated that women comprised 47% of the workforce, with 13% in tier 1 (executive) positions and 45% in tier 2 (general/group manager) roles.

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column7: Of 712 individual employees, 236, or 33.1%, are classified as culturally and linguistically diverse, with English as their second language.

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column7: The total number of Mint employees identifying as Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander is 14, accounting for 2% of the workforce.

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column7: The total number of Mint employees with a disability is 59, representing 8.3% of the workforce.

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column7: The total number of Mint employees identifying as LGBTIQA+ is 36, comprising 5.1% of the workforce.

column6: Ratio of basic salary and remuneration of women to men
column13: The Mint also intends to provide equal opportunities and rewards to all our employees, regardless of gender, disability, or cultural background. The gender pay gap is an area of focus, with the gap between our male and female employees' pay improving this year to 12.2%.
column20: Pay equity, Gender pay gap, Wage equality

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column13: The Mint provides grievance mechanisms designed to support and encourage all our employees and supply chains to identify and escalate issues relating to modern slavery violations. It is consistent with the Whistleblower policy.
column20: Grievance mechanism, Modern slavery, Whistleblower policy

column6: Incidents of discrimination and corrective actions taken
column7: To date, the Mint has not received any reports or allegations relating to actual or suspected modern slavery violations within our business operations. However, as we continue to educate our workforce, develop our due diligence activities, and deepen our engagement with suppliers, we expect to eventually identify an instance of modern slavery in our supply chain.\t

column7: The Mint acknowledges that the precious metals industry operates in jurisdictions with a high prevalence of modern slavery and that there are risks of involvement in modern slavery in operations.

Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The Mint participated in the City of Perth's first Boorloo Heritage Festival in April 2023. The Mint offered gold panning and gem hunt activations in our front garden. Gold panning was also a feature of our display at the WA Day Festival, held over the long weekend of June at Burswood Park.
column20: Corporate Volunteering, Community participation, Community engagement

column6: Operations with local community engagement, impact assessments, and development programs
column13: The Mint has supported Gold Industry Group's national gold education program since its inception, educating school students about the industry's contribution to the economy, the importance of Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths (STEM) subjects and the diverse range of careers available in the sector.
column20: Gold Industry Group, Gold education program, Industry partnerships

column6: Operations with significant actual and potential negative impacts on local communities
New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: The Mint remains committed to the principles of responsible sourcing, which aim to keep all precious metals and other materials in our value chain free of the risk of money laundering, terrorist financing, and human rights abuses and for all our customers and suppliers to operate in a way that respects the natural environment and the communities in which they operate.
column20: Responsible sourcing, Precious metals, Value chain

column6: New suppliers that were screened using social criteria
column13: The Mint's supplier includes mandates about labour practices and modern slavery. These mandates involve confirming in their contracts that there are no violations of modern slavery in any form, reaffirming their commitment to the Mint's supplier code of conduct, conducting an internal assessment of their supply chain to understand better and identify any suspected or potential modern slavery violations, investigate, report and remediate any modern slavery violations.
column20: Contract requirements, Supplier code of conduct, Supply chain assessment

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: In emerging economies, mining operations rely on unskilled labour, which may pose increased human rights and modern slavery risks. Metal transport, particularly in emerging economies, can increase modern slavery risks.
column20: Human rights risks, Emerging economies, Mining operations

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: The secondary precious metals market, including the buying and refining of precious metal scrap, jewellery and other secondary materials, may provide financial support to modern slavery practices as well as directly incur human rights and modern slavery abuse, especially in emerging economies.
column20: Supply chain, Precious metals market, Emerging economies

column6: Negative social impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column13: Investment in precious metals can present risks for money laundering, terrorism finance, corruption, and trade with sanctioned countries and other conflict regions. The risk of modern slavery is considerably higher in conflict countries, and therefore, investment in precious metals may finance modern slavery practices.
column20: Money laundering risks, Terrorism finance risks, Corruption risks

Assessment of the health and safety impacts of product and service categories
column13: Focusing on investment in new equipment and processes in our refinery and coining operations has led to a safer environment for our people and efficiency improvements. There has also been renewed attention on strategic asset management, including preventative maintenance, to reduce operator risks from equipment failure.
column20: Investment in new equipment, Safety enhancement, Workplace safety

column6: Incidents of non-compliance concerning the health and safety impacts of products and services
column13: A significant step towards improving our safety performance has been changing the workplace safety culture around identifying hazards and reporting incidents as they occur. It has led to a higher level of willingness from employees across the business to report concerns and incidents, a shift reflected in the slight rise in TRIFR this year compared to the previous year.
column20: Workplace safety culture, Incident reporting, Safety performance
